title: Pain
content:
Most of us wouldn't feel to bad if we squished a worm; we're a bit saddened when a bird hits a window, apologetic when we stand on a cats tail and punching someone really sucks.

The question really is, when does it become 'alright' to cause significant pain to a creature, in general people have developed 'levels' inert matter and plant life can't feel pain, then there are 'bugs' which its not really worth worrying about, fish and reptiles which we don't care for either, and birds and mammals which we tend to reserve our empathy for. Of course fellow humans are in general [but not always] rated highest.

Now I'm not asking what is *idealy* acceptable, which many people would say covers all pain whatsoever, but rather what is *practically* acceptable, for example many people see it quite unobjectionable to torutre fish for hours by thrusting a hook through them then letting them choke to death on land yet only the meanest person would do the same to say, a duck.

So... yeah. Whats your limit?Szevvy Forever!
And Spleen never!

[img]http://img.photobucket.com/albums/v410/Gannalev/rcwn.jpg[/img]

"No one should be here."
-Levellord

title: Re: Pain
content:
I haven't voted yet, I'll have to think about it. If this is about what one could or couldn't personally do, then I'd probably say that even bugs matter. Some insects I haven't felt too bad for crushing, for example some annoying mosquitos or whatever. However, I always try to avoid stepping on worms when it has rained, and feel bad if I crush a snail, for example. But couldn't torture or kill any larger animal, such as fish. Perhaps the size of these animals has something to do with it, or perhaps their non-bugginess. I don't like bugs that much, even if I don't want to kill them. However, seems I still don't feel too bad about eating killed animals. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-halloween.gif[/img] I guess I'd say that killing for the sake of killing isn't acceptable, however, I guess it doesn't matter too much if one crushes a mosquito once in a while.3D Realms: "Do you think there'll ever be a sequel to your game(s)?"
Tom Hall: "If I owned Keen, there sure would be. I don't consider that GBA game canon by any means."

title: Re: Pain
content:
This is one of those questions that just ends up with the thought that there is no right answer, just your answer.
The world isn't black and white.

Sure, even bugs matter, and I generally leave them alone, but I'd be lying if I said I hadn't killed any mosquitos by standing ovation because they bugged me.
It's not like I haven't crushed a million lifeforms by accidently and totally obliviously stepping on them, or even just by being.

By being born, a matter you had no choice in, you are given many responsibilities, some of which simply go way over anybody's head, and just a wide variety of contrasting guidelines you can choose to follow, or just ignore.
Who is to judge what is right and what's not anyway.Retodon8
Sheep happens! [url=http://keen.retodon8.net/][img]http://retodon8.net/Keen/Graphics/K1_nme_Yorp.gif[/img][/url]

title: Re: Pain
content:
We're talking pain though, so squishing a mosquito or a fly doesn't matter, because ideally it'd be dead before it realised what happened. Pulling the wings off a fly and then watching it run around presumably counts, because it would feel pain.

So in that case I vote "even bugs matter", because I find any sort of lifeform in distress a little sad - I even make sure I squish the living daylights out of cockroaches, because I read somewhere they can survive for days without a body until they starve to death, and I think even allowing that to happen is a little cruel [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-wink.gif[/img]

title: Re: Pain
content:
Well, I think this is a question of what you'd *practically* do. Would you go fishing? Would you swat a bug? Would you feel bad about it?Szevvy Forever!
And Spleen never!

title: Re: lskfdj
content:
I think it is an interesting argument to hear the reasons for vegetarianism --which is tied to what you were saying. What constitutes unreasonable pain, and what actually feels pain?

I think it is not keeping the whole perspective to just notice what feels pain. Plants are still alive, and so are bugs. Niether of them have brains like animals do, but they are most definitely living creatures.

I think, however, that squishing a bug and jumping on dog are not exactly the same thing in that they have different effects. Dogs feel pain, bugs do not. You're torturing something as opposed to quickly killing a bug. *shrugs* I think in this case, pain is what keeps the action from being protecting oneself from annoyance and sadism.~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
I've changed a lot since my last time on this forum...

title: Re: lskfdj
content:
Bugs don't feel pain?
(And bugs aren't animals? Sure they are!)

I've seen ants REALLY pick up the pace after being aimed at with sun light through a magnifying glass, I've seen insects spasm when being hit, drowned, burned, having their legs pulled out, and so on.
Worms and snails (considered "bugs" by some, although I think the official definition is just "insects", not sure) for instance also freak out if not-so-nice things happen to them.
Are you really sure they don't feel pain?
They feel something, otherwise they wouldn't react.

Judging from the outside I have no reason bugs feel any less pain than the dog you mention.
As a matter of fact, the only person I truly know feels pain, is me.
Every other person could be faking as far as I know, I have no way of ever finding out for sure.Retodon8
Sheep happens! [url=http://keen.retodon8.net/][img]http://retodon8.net/Keen/Graphics/K1_nme_Yorp.gif[/img][/url]

title: Pain, without love. Pain, can't get enough.
content:
I don't know to what degree plants and animals feel pain in the same way we do, but I prefer to behave as if they do, just to be safe. I do my best to avoid killing an insect, and move it out of the way of danger if I can. I minimise any factors that may put them in a position where they are a menace (ie. dirty plates, crumbs, etc). I also try to rescue drowning bugs if they're still alive.

But I cannot spend every moment of my existence making sure I'm not stepping on a creature (who knows how many I'm killing just by walking across my lawn). Besides, they don't live that long, and will probably be eaten by something soon enough.

There are times where I will kill a mosquito or a fly, or a spider that poses a particularly great threat to my own wellbeing (ie. whitetails), but I make sure it's an instantaneous death--THWACK! No agonisingly slow deaths by poisonous substances.

As Ret says, it's impossible to tell for sure what another being feels. We can only judge from their outside reactions, but plants and bugs don't have such expressive capabilities as us 'higher' animals, so who knows whether pain is excruciating to them as it can be for ourselves.

title: Re: Pain, without love. Pain, can't get enough.
content:
Indeed, their reaction could just be something triggered by something (like sudden warmth), and so on. However, it's interesting to think into how small space a consciousness (or self-consciousness) can fit, and in what different forms it manifests (couldn't think of any better word here). How do we really know what thinks and what doesn't? The thoughts don't necessarily need to be anything like ours.3D Realms: "Do you think there'll ever be a sequel to your game(s)?"
Tom Hall: "If I owned Keen, there sure would be. I don't consider that GBA game canon by any means."

title: Re: Pain, without love. Pain, can't get enough.
content:
As I'm getting more conscious on what I am and what my surroundings are, I find it harder to do some of the animal related stuff. Ex.: We ate chicken a while ago. I normally love chicken, but now I kinda felt bad for it.

No I'm not turning vegetarian, we are who we are, that much I know. I think I liked the chicken less because there still was half a neck visible, which grossed me out in a way...

Still, hurting animals for no valid reason is a stupid thought, just as hurting people (or even killing them) for almost no valid reason is. Especially as we're THINKING human beings.____________
Don't think of me as an ordinary man.

Even though I am an ordinary man.

Ah, [url=http://DaVince.sitesled.com/]site.[/url]

title: Re: Pain, without love. Pain, can't get enough.
content:
[quote]Quote:[hr]I've seen ants REALLY pick up the pace after being aimed at with sun light through a magnifying glass, I've seen insects spasm when being hit, drowned, burned, having their legs pulled out, and so on.
Worms and snails (considered "bugs" by some, although I think the official definition is just "insects", not sure) for instance also freak out if not-so-nice things happen to them.
Are you really sure they don't feel pain?
They feel something, otherwise they wouldn't react.[hr][/quote]

First of all snails and worms are not insects, go back to your biology classes.

Secondly your argumentation is wrong. Think back of your childhood you had those little mechanic toys you could wind up so that they would walk, a dog for example. Imagine you wind up such a dog and instead of letting it walk you put it on his back. It would spawn because it is supposed to walk but it can't. Would that probe that mechanic toys have feelings?

When something looks like something you can relate to doesn't mean that it are the same things. Remember that.

...some people...-----------------

title: Re: Pain, without love. Pain, can't get enough.
content:
I never said snails and worms are insects.
I said some people consider them bugs.
I'll look it up...
Wikipedia does in fact [url=http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bug]mention[/url]: "The term "bug" is often used informally to refer to, variously, insects, other arthropods, snails, slugs, etc.".
It als [url=http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hemiptera]says[/url] that the order of Hemiptera is the "true bug", but since it doesn't say what language the word originates from, what it really "means", I don't see why those things qualify and others don't.

Anyway, I won't go back to biology classes, I said nothing wrong that I can see.
Edit: Wait, I thought "bug" was synonymous with "insect", so I may have been wrong there, depending on which definitions you agree with exactly.
(I dropped biology when I could pick my own selection of classes, because bio classes were dumb.
I never paid any attention, just did my homework, which I found very simple, too simple, and always got very good grades.
I'm sure it became more difficult in later classes for those who picked it though, but I didn't.)

As for the mechanical toys.
Firstly it's not the same thing, the mechanical toy will still move, if perhaps akwardly, in its original manner.
An animal will move more randomly, much faster than it would normally in some cases, squirming, moving any appendages strangely, definately looking like its writhing in pain.
Secondly, I wasn't trying to say ants (or other animals) feel pain, I was just saying that they sure look like they do.
It really is scientifically impossible to tell if anyone, anything experiences pain, besides yourself.

[quote]Quote:[hr]When something looks like something you can relate to doesn't mean that it are the same things. Remember that.[hr][/quote]

That is very close to the point I was trying to make... does that mean we agree after all?

[quote]Quote:[hr]...some people...[hr][/quote]

Yes...?
Some people what?Retodon8

title: Re: Pain
content:
[quote]Quote:[hr]As for the mechanical toys.
Firstly it's not the same thing, the mechanical toy will still move, if perhaps akwardly, in its original manner.
An animal will move more randomly, much faster than it would normally in some cases, squirming, moving any appendages strangely, definately looking like its writhing in pain.[hr][/quote]
That they move randomly doesn't mean anything, it could just be the way the mechanism was triggered.

[quote]Quote:[hr]Secondly, I wasn't trying to say ants (or other animals) feel pain, I was just saying that they sure look like they do.[hr][/quote]
You were obviously reasoning that they would because it looked they felt pain. I disproved that reason.

[quote]Quote:[hr]It really is scientifically impossible to tell if anyone, anything experiences pain, besides yourself.[hr][/quote]
I highly doubt that, but that's not the discussion I want.

Right, that obviously was also your point....-----------------

title: Re: Pain
content:
About the randomness, I am just saying that if I tie you up in a lift that I slowly lower into boiling water, you'll also react by randomly moving trying to get out.
Actually I have no idea how exactly a human would react to this, luckily, (I heard about lobsters though) but looking at human pain in general this probably isn't far off.
So, your argument also holds true for other humans; it could just be the way the mechanism is triggered, the way the human is programmed to react, without feeling pain.

I really wasn't reasoning it is proven that animals do feel pain because of their reactions, even if it seems obvious to you that I was.
I was just saying that it makes it look like they do, because it resembles to how humans, or more precisely I would react in such a situation.
It could be a coincidence, it could not be.
(I could program a robot to react like humans would in all kinds of painful situation, but this doesn't mean it'd feel pain... depending on your definition of pain of course, I could also program the robot to try and avoid these sensory inputs, but even then it wouldn't necesarily mean those sensations would be unpleasant to it, like how my definition of pain is.)
Like I said, this can't be proven, so I won't claim I have proven animals feel pain.

If you really doubt that either point (do or don't feel pain) of view can't be proven, try and find proof, and either you'll be convinced, or you should publish your proof and earn a Nobel prize or something. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img]
Anyway, you say this isn't the interesting part of this discussion to you, so I guess you won't try.
I personally think this is one of the most interesting parts of this discussion, which is why I keep replying. [img]http://www.classicgaming.com/cc314/msgboard/emotikeen-smile.gif[/img] Retodon8
